prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have picked the resolution element of to minimize the data rate while still being able to achieve ~40-50 elements over the expected linewidth, in the event the line is brighter than expected, while also minimizing the data rate. We have placed the spectral windows to fully cover the receiver side bands, with at least ~5 channels overlap to ensure a continuous spectrum.
We require no special imaging requirements. We have requested ALMA observations with synthesized beams to match the size of the sources from Stacey et al. 2010.

To determine our sensitivity we have taken our tentative upper limit to CO(2-1) line from ALMA Cycle -2 for 3c368 and the upper limits from PdBI by CO-I S. Hailey-Dunsheath for PG1241, F22241, and PKS0125. For F22241 and PKS0215 we scale the CO(2-1) upper limits to our targeted lines of CO(5-4) and CO(3-2) respectively following the CO ratios from Bournaud et al. 2015 for a high-z star forming disk to get a minimum line flux we would expect for the higher-j transition. We have assumed a linewidth of ~250 km/s to estimate the peak flux and then require of 5 sigma detection in a 80 km/s channel for 3C368 and a 10-sigma detection to the upper limits of PG1241, F22241 and PKS0125. For PG1241 we assume a 50 km/s channel width, while PKS0125 and PG1241 we request 10 km/s channel widths to ensure we are below the continuum to line RMS ratio limit of ~1000. We have requested a ALMA beam size to match the source sizes as noted in Table 1. We have selected a channel widths so that we can have at least ~3 channels across our estimated linewidth, while keeping the requested total integration time to less than ~120 minutes per source. Our achieved continuum sensitivity does not drive our time requests, however we expect to strongly detect the continuum regardless.

We have picked the resolution element of to minimize the data rate while still being able to achieve ~40-50 elements over the expected linewidth, in the event the line is brighter than expected, while also minimizing the data rate. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose using ALMA Cycle-3 to observe CO lines in four [CII] 158 m emitters whose bolometric luminosity is dominated by an AGN. These observations are vital to our interpretation of the [CII] line from sources in the high-z universe. With our spectrometers ZEUS-1 and 2 we pioneered the use of the [CII] line to study the ISM in galaxies at z~1-2. We unexpectedly found that ULIRGs (> 10^12 L) in the early universe span a wide range of [CII]/FIR luminosity ratios, ~10^-4 to ~10^-2, with AGN dominated systems usually <10^-3. The typical PDR emission mode for [CII] can produce these various ratios, but additional [CII] contributions from XDRs, shocks, ionized gas and/or low-metallicity environments could also be important. Contamination to the FIR by the AGN could also impact our interpretation of the ratio. Understanding the [CII] emission in our sources requires a measure of their molecular gas, which we propose here to obtain with ALMA. Or project will provide important details on the processes that are important for producing the [CII] line in high-z AGN dominated systems with implications for future studies of the earlier universe with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
Submillimeter Astrophysics Group, California Institute of Technology
